nodes.label: Short title
nodes.summary: This Act may be cited as theFair Work Act 2009.

nodes.label: Commencement
nodes.summary: (1)Each provision of this Act specified in column 1 of the table commences, or is taken to have commenced, in accordance with column 2 of the table. Any other statement in column 2 has effect accordin...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: Each provision of this Act specified in column 1 of the table commences, or is taken to have commenced, in accordance with column 2 of the table. Any other statement in column 2 has effect according t...

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: Column 3 of the table contains additional information that is not part of this Act. Information in this column may be added to or edited in any published version of this Act.

nodes.label: Object of this Act
nodes.summary:
The object of this Act is to provide a balanced framework for cooperative and productive workplace relations that promotes national economic prosperity and social inclusion for all Australians by:
(a)...

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: providing workplace relations laws that are fair to working Australians, promote job security and gender equality, are flexible for businesses, promote productivity and economic growth for Australia’s...

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: ensuring a guaranteed safety net of fair, relevant and enforceable minimum terms and conditions through the National Employment Standards, modern awards and national minimum wage orders; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: ensuring that the guaranteed safety net of fair, relevant and enforceable minimum wages and conditions can no longer be undermined by the making of statutory individual employment agreements of any ki...

nodes.label: Paragraph ca
nodes.summary: ensuring a safety net of fair and relevant minimum terms and conditions for regulated workers through enforceable minimum standards orders and related measures; and

nodes.label: Paragraph caa
nodes.summary: ensuring a safety net of fair and relevant minimum terms and conditions for persons in a road transport contractual chain through enforceable road transport contractual chain orders and through road t...

nodes.label: Paragraph cb
nodes.summary: providing appropriate remedies in relation to unfair terms of services contracts; and

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: assisting employees to balance their work and family responsibilities by providing for flexible working arrangements; and

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: enabling fairness and representation at work and the prevention of discrimination by recognising the right to freedom of association and the right to be represented, protecting against unfair treatmen...

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: achieving productivity and fairness through an emphasis on enterprise‑level collective bargaining underpinned by simple good faith bargaining obligations and clear rules governing industrial action; a...

nodes.label: Paragraph g
nodes.summary: acknowledging the special circumstances of small and medium‑sized businesses.

nodes.label: Guide to this Act
nodes.summary:
Overview of this Act
(1)This Act is about workplace relations. It:
(a)provides for terms and conditions of employment (Chapter2); and
(b)sets out rights and responsibilities of employees, employers an...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: This Act is about workplace relations. It: Overview of this Act

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: provides for terms and conditions of employment (Chapter2); and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: sets out rights and responsibilities of employees, employers and organisations in relation to that employment (Chapter3); and

nodes.label: Paragraph ba
nodes.summary: provides for minimum terms and conditions for regulated workers (Chapter3A); and

nodes.label: Paragraph bb
nodes.summary: sets out measures to deal with unfair terms of services contracts (Chapter3A); and

nodes.label: Paragraph bc
nodes.summary: provides for minimum terms and conditions for persons in a road transport contractual chain (Chapter3B); and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: provides for compliance with, and enforcement of, this Act (Chapter4); and

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: provides for the administration of this Act by establishing the Fair Work Commission and the Office of the Fair Work Ombudsman (Chapter5); and

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: deals with other matters relating to the above (Chapter6). Overview of the rest of this Chapter

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The rest of this Chapter deals with:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: definitions that are used in this Act (Part1‑2); and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the application of this Act (Part1‑3), including how this Act interacts with certain State and Territory laws and its geographical application;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: certain matters relating to the road transport industry (Part1‑4). Definitions

nodes.summary: Schedule1 contains application, saving and transitional provisions relating to amendments of this Act.

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: Chapter3 sets out rights and responsibilities of national system employees, national system employers, organisations and others (such as independent contractors and industrial associations).

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: Part3‑1 provides general workplace protections. It:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: protects workplace rights; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: protects freedom of association and involvement in lawful industrial activities; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: provides other protections, including protection from discrimination.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: Part3‑2 deals with unfair dismissal of national system employees, and the granting of remedies when that happens.

nodes.summary: advertising rates of pay.

nodes.label: Subsection 8

nodes.summary: the performance of work by an employee in a manner different from that in which it is customarily performed, or the adoption of a practice in relation to work by an employee, the result of which is a...

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: a ban, limitation or restriction on the performance of work by an employee or on the acceptance of or offering for work by an employee;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: a failure or refusal by employees to attend for work or a failure or refusal to perform any work at all by employees who attend for work;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: the lockout of employees from their employment by the employer of the employees.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: However,industrial actiondoes not include the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: action by employees that is authorised or agreed to by the employer of the employees;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: action by an employer that is authorised or agreed to by, or on behalf of, employees of the employer;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: action by an employee if:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: the action was based on a reasonable concern of the employee about an imminent risk to his or her health or safety; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the employee did not unreasonably fail to comply with a direction of his or her employer to perform other available work, whether at the same or another workplace, that was safe and appropriate for th...

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: An employerlocks outemployees from their employment if the employer prevents the employees from performing work under their contracts of employment without terminating those contracts.

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: This section applies to a regulated worker and to a regulated business if:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the regulated worker is covered by a minimum standards order, or is mentioned in an application for a minimum standards order as a regulated worker who would be covered by the order if it is made; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the regulated business is covered by the same minimum standards order, or is mentioned in an application for the same minimum standards order as a regulated business that would be covered by the order...

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: if the regulated business is a digital labour platform operator—the regulated worker is an employee‑like worker:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: from whom the digital labour platform operator receives services under a services contract; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: who performs services under a services contract that was arranged or facilitated through or by means of the digital labour platform operated by the digital labour platform operator; and

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: if the regulated business is a road transport business—the regulated road transport contractor performs work under the services contract for the regulated business.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: Industrial action, in relation to the regulated worker and the regulated business, means action of any of the following kinds:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the performance of work under the services contract by the regulated worker in a manner different from that in which it is customarily performed, or the adoption of a practice in relation to work by t...

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: a ban, limitation or restriction on the performance of work under the services contract by the regulated worker or on the acceptance of or offering for work by the regulated worker;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: a failure or refusal by the regulated worker to attend for work under the services contract or, if the regulated worker attends for work, a refusal to perform any work at all;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: the lockout of the regulated worker by the regulated business.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The action referred to in paragraph(2)(a), (b) or (c) must be directed against the regulated business (whether or not the regulated business is a party to the services contract).

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: However, industrial action does not include the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: action by a regulated worker that is authorised or agreed to by the regulated business that is covered by the same minimum standards order as the regulated worker;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: action by a regulated business referred to in paragraph(2)(d) that is authorised or agreed to by, or on behalf of, regulated workers covered by the same minimum standards order asthe regulated busines...

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: action by the regulated worker, if:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: the action was based on a reasonable concern of the regulated worker about an imminent risk to the health or safety of the regulated worker; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the regulated worker did not unreasonably fail to comply with a direction of the regulated business to perform other available work, whether at the same or another workplace, that was safe and appropr...

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: A regulated businesslocks outa regulated worker if either or both of the following apply:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the regulated business prevents the regulated worker from performing work under a services contract without terminating the contract;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if the regulated business is a digital labour platform operator and the regulated worker is an employee‑like worker—the digital labour platform operator modifies, limits or suspends the employee‑like...

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the making and varying of road transport minimum standards orders and road transport guidelines;

nodes.summary: the making and varying of road transport contractual chain orders and road transport contractual chain guidelines;

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: The Road Transport Advisory Group consists of such members as the Minister from time to time appoints.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: In appointing the members of the Road Transport Advisory Group, the Minister must ensure that the membership consists of persons who are members of or who are nominated by the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more regulated road transport contractors;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of one or more road transport businesses.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: A member of the Road Transport Advisory Group holds office for the period specified in the instrument of appointment. The period must not exceed 3 years.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: The Minister may revoke a person’s appointment to the Road Transport Advisory Group.

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: The President may give the Road Transport Advisory Group directions as to the way in which the body is to carry out its functions.

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: The President may appoint a member of the Expert Panel for the road transport industry to chair the Road Transport Advisory Group.

nodes.label: Maximum weekly hours

Maximum weekly hours of work
(1)An employer must not request or require an employee to work more than the following number of hours in a week unless the additional hours are reasonable:
(a)for a full‑...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: An employer must not request or require an employee to work more than the following number of hours in a week unless the additional hours are reasonable: Maximum weekly hours of work

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: for a full‑time employee—38 hours; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: for an employee who is not a full‑time employee—the lesser of:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: 38 hours; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the employee’s ordinary hours of work in a week. Employee may refuse to work unreasonable additional hours

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The employee may refuse to work additional hours (beyond those referred to in paragraph(1)(a) or (b)) if they are unreasonable. Determining whether additional hours are reasonable

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: In determining whether additional hours are reasonable or unreasonable for the purposes of subsections(1) and (2), the following must be taken into account:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: any risk to employee health and safety from working the additional hours;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employee’s personal circumstances, including family responsibilities;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: the needs of the workplace or enterprise in which the employee is employed;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: whether the employee is entitled to receive overtime payments, penalty rates or other compensation for, or a level of remuneration that reflects an expectation of, working additional hours;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: any notice given by the employer of any request or requirement to work the additional hours;

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: any notice given by the employee of his or her intention to refuse to work the additional hours;

nodes.label: Paragraph g
nodes.summary: the usual patterns of work in the industry, or the part of an industry, in which the employee works;

nodes.label: Paragraph h
nodes.summary: the nature of the employee’s role, and the employee’s level of responsibility;

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: whether the additional hours are in accordance with averaging terms included under section63 in a modern award or enterprise agreement that applies to the employee, or with an averaging arrangement ag...

nodes.label: Paragraph j
nodes.summary: any other relevant matter. Authorised leave or absence treated as hours worked

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: For the purposes of subsection(1), the hours an employee works in a week are taken to include any hours of leave, or absence, whether paid or unpaid, that the employee takes in the week and that are a...

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: by the employee’s employer; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: by or under a term or condition of the employee’s employment; or

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, or an instrument in force under such a law.

Responding to the request

nodes.summary: If, under subsection65(1), an employee requests an employer for a change in working arrangements relating to circumstances that apply to the employee, the employer must give the employee a written res...

nodes.summary: The response must:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: state that the employer grants the request; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if, following discussion between the employer and the employee, the employer and the employee agree to a change to the employee’s working arrangements that differs from that set out in the request—set...

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The employer may refuse the request only if:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the employer has:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: discussed the request with the employee; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: genuinely tried to reach an agreement with the employee about making changes to the employee’s working arrangements to accommodate the circumstances mentioned in subsection(1); and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employer and the employee have not reached such an agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: the employer has had regard to the consequences of the refusal for the employee; and

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: the refusal is on reasonable business grounds.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: To avoid doubt, subparagraph(3)(a)(ii) does not require the employer to agree to a change to the employee’s working arrangements if the employer would have reasonable business grounds for refusing a r...

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: Without limiting what are reasonable business grounds for the purposes of paragraph(3)(d) and subsection(4), reasonable business grounds for refusing a request include the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: that the new working arrangements requested would be too costly for the employer;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: that there is no capacity to change the working arrangements of other employees to accommodate the new working arrangements requested;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: that it would be impractical to change the working arrangements of other employees, or recruit new employees, to accommodate the new working arrangements requested;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: that the new working arrangements requested would be likely to result in a significant loss in efficiency or productivity;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: that the new working arrangements requested would be likely to have a significant negative impact on customer service. Employer must explain grounds for refusal

nodes.label: Subsection 6

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: without limiting paragraph(a) of this subsection:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: set out the changes (other than the requested change) in the employee’s working arrangements that would accommodate, to any extent, the circumstances mentioned in subsection(1) and that the employer w...

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: state that there are no such changes; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: either:

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: set out the effect of sections65B and 65C. Genuinely trying to reach an agreement

nodes.label: Subsection 7
nodes.summary: This section does not affect, and is not affected by, the meaning of the expression “genuinely trying to reach an agreement”, or any variant of the expression, as used elsewhere in this Act.

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: In the first instance, the parties to the dispute must attempt to resolve the dispute at the workplace level, by discussions between the parties. FWC may deal with disputes

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: If discussions at the workplace level do not resolve the dispute, a party to the dispute may refer the dispute to the FWC.

nodes.summary: If a dispute is referred under subsection(3):

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the FWC must first deal with the dispute by means other than arbitration, unless there are exceptional circumstances; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration in accordance with section65C. Representatives

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: The employer or employee may appoint a person or industrial association to provide the employer or employee (as the case may be) with support or representation for the purposes of:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: resolving the dispute; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the FWC dealing with the dispute.

nodes.label: Paragraph d

nodes.label: Other rights and obligations
Subsection 1
nodes.summary: An employer must not do any of the following in order to avoid any right or obligation under this Division:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: reduce or vary an employee’s hours of work;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: change the employee’s pattern of work;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: terminate an employee’s employment.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: Nothing in this Division:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: requires an employee to change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment under this Division; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: permits an employer to require an employee to change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment under this Division; or

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: requires an employer to increase the hours of work of an employee who gives a notification to change to full‑time employment or part‑time employment under this Division.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: To avoid doubt, each of the following is a workplace right within the meaning of Part3‑1:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: giving an employer a notification under section66AAB;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: receiving a response from an employer in accordance with section66AAC;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: being taken to be a full‑time employee or part‑time employee under section66AAD;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: receiving an offer or notice in accordance with sections66B and 66C;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: accepting an offer and receiving a notice under section66E;

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: participating in a dispute about the operation of this Division in accordance with sections66M and 66MA.

An employee is entitled to 12 months of unpaid parental leave if:

(i)the birth of a child of the employee or the employee’s spouse ordefactopartner; or

nodes.label: Subsection 1

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The employee must take the leave in a single continuous period. When birth‑related leave must start and end

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: If the leave is birth‑related leave for an employee who is pregnant with, or gives birth to, the child, the period of leave may start:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: up to 6 weeks before the expected date of birth of the child; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: earlier, if the employer and employee so agree; or

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child; but must end during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: If the leave is birth‑related leave but subsection(3) does not apply, the period of leave must start and end during the 24‑month period starting on the date of birth of the child. When adoption‑relate...

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: If the leave is adoption‑related leave, the period of leave must start and end during the 24‑month period starting on the day of placement of the child. Limit on amount of leave

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: The employee may take unpaid parental leave under this section only if the period of leave is no longer than 12 months, less the employee’s notional flexible period.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: The employee may take the flexible unpaid parental leave whether or not the employee has taken unpaid parental leave under another provision of this Division in relation to the child.

nodes.label: Paragraph b

nodes.label: Subsection 10
nodes.summary: An employee is not entitled to take flexible unpaid parental leave in relation to a child if:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the child and another child:

nodes.label: Paragraph i

nodes.label: Paragraph ii

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employee takes flexible unpaid parental leave in relation to the other child. Interaction with section71

nodes.label: Subsection 11
nodes.summary: Flexible unpaid parental leave taken by an employee is an exception to the rules in section71 about:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: taking the employee’s unpaid parental leave in a single continuous period; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: when the employee’s period of unpaid parental leave must start.

nodes.label: Subsection 12
nodes.summary: Despite anything in subsection(11), flexible unpaid parental leave cannot be used to break up a period of unpaid parental leave taken under section71.

nodes.summary: taking the employee’s unpaid parental leave in a single continuous period; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: when the employee’s period of unpaid parental leave must start.

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: The employee is not required to comply with section74 in relation to the period of leave.

nodes.summary: the original leave period has started.

nodes.label: Responding to requests for extension of unpaid parental leave
nodes.summary:
Responding to the request

nodes.summary: If, under subsection76(1), an employee requests an employer to agree to an extension of unpaid parental leave for the employee for a further period of up to 12 months immediately following the end of...

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The response must:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: state that the employer grants the request; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if, following discussion between the employer and the employee, the employer and the employee agree to an extension of unpaid parental leave for the employee for a period that differs from the period...

nodes.summary: subject to subsection(3)—state that the employer refuses the request and include the matters required by subsection(6).

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The employer may refuse the request only if:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the employer has:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: discussed the request with the employee; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: genuinely tried to reach an agreement with the employee about an extension of the period of unpaid parental leave for the employee; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employer and the employee have not reached such an agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: the employer has had regard to the consequences of the refusal for the employee; and

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: the refusal is on reasonable business grounds.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: To avoid doubt, subparagraph(3)(a)(ii) does not require the employer to agree to an extension of the period of unpaid parental leave for the employee if the employer would have reasonable business gro...

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: Without limiting what are reasonable business grounds for the purposes of paragraph(3)(d) and subsection(4), reasonable business grounds for refusing a request include the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: that the extension of the period of unpaid parental leave requested by the employee would be too costly for the employer;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: that there is no capacity to change the working arrangements of other employees to accommodate the extension of the period of unpaid parental leave requested by the employee;

nodes.label: Paragraph c

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: that the extension of the period of unpaid parental leave requested by the employee would be likely to result in a significant loss in efficiency or productivity;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: that the extension of the period of unpaid parental leave requested by the employee would be likely to have a significant negative impact on customer service. Employer must explain grounds for refusal

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: If the employer refuses the request, the written response under subsection(1) must:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: include details of the reasons for the refusal; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: without limiting paragraph(a) of this subsection:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: set out the extension of the period of unpaid parental leave for the employee (other than the period requested by the employee) that the employer would be willing to agree to; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: state that there is no extension of the period that the employer would be willing to agree to; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: either:

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: set out the effect of sections76B and 76C. Genuinely trying to reach an agreement

nodes.label: Subsection 7
nodes.summary: This section does not affect, and is not affected by, the meaning of the expression “genuinely trying to reach an agreement”, or any variant of the expression, as used elsewhere in this Act.

Application of this section

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: This section applies to a dispute between an employer and an employee that relates to a request by the employee to the employer under subsection76(1) to agree to an extension of unpaid parental leave...

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the employer has refused the request; or

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: In the first instance, the parties to the dispute must attempt to resolve the dispute at the workplace level, by discussions between the parties. FWC may deal with disputes

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: If discussions at the workplace level do not resolve the dispute, a party to the dispute may refer the dispute to the FWC.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: If a dispute is referred under subsection(3):

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the FWC must first deal with the dispute by means other than arbitration, unless there are exceptional circumstances; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration in accordance with section76C. Representatives

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: The employer or employee may appoint a person or industrial association to provide the employer or employee (as the case may be) with support or representation for the purposes of:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: resolving the dispute; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the FWC dealing with the dispute.

nodes.label: Arbitration
nodes.summary:
(1)For the purposes of paragraph76B(4)(b), the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration by making any of the following orders:
(a)if the employer has not given the employee a written response to t...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: For the purposes of paragraph76B(4)(b), the FWC may deal with the dispute by arbitration by making any of the following orders:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: if the employer has not given the employee a written response to the request under section76A—an order that the employer be taken to have refused the request;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if the employer refused the request:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: an order that the employer grant the request; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: an order that the employer agree to an extension of unpaid parental leave for the employee for a further period of up to 12 months (other than the period requested by the employee) immediately followi...

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: if the FWC is satisfied that the employer has not responded, or has not responded adequately, to the employee’s request under section76A—an order that the employer take such further steps as the FWC c...

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: subject to subsection(4) of this section:

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: In making an order under subsection(1), the FWC must take into account fairness between the employer and the employee.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The FWC must not make an order under paragraph(1)(c) or (d) that would be inconsistent with:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a provision of this Act; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: a term of a fair work instrument (other than an order made under that paragraph) that, immediately before the order is made, applies to the employer and employee.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: The FWC may make an order under paragraph(1)(d) only if the FWC is satisfied that there is no reasonable prospect of the dispute being resolved without the making of such an order.

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: If the FWC makes an order under paragraph(1)(a), the employer is taken to have refused the request.

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: If the FWC makes an order under paragraph(1)(b), the grounds on which the employer refuses the request are taken:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: for an order made under subparagraph(1)(b)(i)—to be reasonable business grounds; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: for an order made under subparagraph(1)(b)(ii)—not to be reasonable business grounds. Contravening an order under subsection(1)

nodes.label: Subsection 7
nodes.summary: A person must not contravene a term of an order made under subsection(1).

nodes.label: Reducing period of unpaid parental leave
nodes.summary: If the employer agrees, an employee whose period of unpaid parental leave has started may reduce the period of unpaid parental leave the employee takes.

nodes.label: Effect of stillbirth or death of child on unpaid parental leave

Stillbirth—preserving entitlement to birth‑related leave
(1)If:
(a)a child is stillborn; and
(b)an employee would have been entitled to unpaid parental leave that is birth‑related leave, if the child...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: If: Stillbirth—preserving entitlement to birth‑related leave

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a child is stillborn; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: an employee would have been entitled to unpaid parental leave that is birth‑related leave, if the child had been born alive; then the employee is taken to be entitled to the unpaid parental leave, des...

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: Astillbornchild is a child:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: who weighs at least 400 grams at delivery or whose period of gestation was at least 20 weeks; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: who has not breathed since delivery; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: whose heart has not beaten since delivery.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The provisions of this Division have effect in relation to the employee as if the birth of a child included the stillbirth of a child. Stillbirth or death of child—cancelling leave or returning to wor...

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: If a child is stillborn, or dies during the 24‑month period starting on the child’s date of birth, then an employee who is entitled to a period of unpaid parental leave in relation to the child may:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: before the period of leave starts, give the employee’s employer written notice cancelling the leave; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if the period of leave has started, give the employee’s employer written notice that the employee wishes to return to work on a specified day.

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: For the purposes of paragraph(4)(b), the specified day must be at least 4 weeks after the employer receives the notice.

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: If the employee takes action under subsection(4), the employee’s entitlement to unpaid parental leave in relation to the child ends:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: if the action is taken under paragraph(4)(a)—immediately after the cancellation of the leave; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if the action is taken under paragraph(4)(b)—immediately before the specified day. Interaction with section77

nodes.label: Subsection 7
nodes.summary: Subsections(4) to (6) do not limit section77 (which deals with the employee reducing the period of unpaid parental leave with the agreement of the employer).

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: is stillborn; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: dies during the 24‑month period starting on the child’s date of birth.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The employer may give the employee written notice requiring the employee to return to work on a specified day.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The specified day:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: must be at least 4 weeks after the notice is given to the employee; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if the leave is birth‑related leave taken by an employee who has given birth—must not be earlier than 6 weeks after the date of birth of the child.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: The employee’s entitlement to unpaid parental leave in relation to the child ends immediately before the specified day.

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: an employee, whether before or after the birth of the child, gives notice in accordance with section74 of the taking of a period of unpaid parental leave (theoriginal leave period) in relation to the...

nodes.summary: If the employee and employer so agree, then the following rules have effect:

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the permitted work period does not break the continuity of the original leave period;

nodes.summary: The permitted work period ends at the earliest of the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the time agreed by the employee and employer;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the end of the day of the child’s first discharge from hospital after birth;

nodes.summary: Only one period may be agreed to under subsection(1) for which the employee will not take unpaid parental leave in relation to the child. Evidence

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: that paragraph(1)(a) applies in relation to the child;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: that the employee is fit for work.

nodes.label: Subsection 7
nodes.summary: Without limiting subsection(6), an employer may require the evidence referred to in that subsection to be a medical certificate.

nodes.label: Entitlement to be absent from employment on public holiday

Employee entitled to be absent on public holiday

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: An employee is entitled to be absent from his or her employment on a day or part‑day that is a public holiday in the place where the employee is based for work purposes. Employee entitled to be absent...

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: However, an employer may request an employee to work on a public holiday if the request is reasonable.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: If an employer requests an employee to work on a public holiday, the employee may refuse the request if:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the request is not reasonable; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the refusal is reasonable.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: In determining whether a request, or a refusal of a request, to work on a public holiday is reasonable,the following must be taken into account:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the nature of the employer’s workplace or enterprise (including its operational requirements), and the nature of the work performed by the employee;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employee’s personal circumstances, including family responsibilities;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: whether the employee could reasonably expect that the employer might request work on the public holiday;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: whether the employee is entitled to receive overtime payments, penalty rates or other compensation for, or a level of remuneration that reflects an expectation of, work on the public holiday;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: the type of employment of the employee (for example, whether full‑time, part‑time, casual or shiftwork);

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: the amount of notice in advance of the public holiday given by the employer when making the request;

nodes.label: Paragraph g
nodes.summary: in relation to the refusal of a request—the amount of notice in advance of the public holiday given by the employee when refusing the request;

nodes.label: Paragraph h
nodes.summary: any other relevant matter.

nodes.label: Relationship with other Commonwealth laws
nodes.summary: This Part establishes minimum standards and so is intended to supplement, and not to override, entitlements under other laws of the Commonwealth.

nodes.label: Guide to this Part
nodes.summary: This Part provides for the FWC to make, vary and revoke modern awards. Modern awards may set minimum terms and conditions for national system employees in particular industries or occupations. Modern...

nodes.summary: modern award minimum wages can also be varied under this Part, but only for work value reasons or in other limited circumstances;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: modern award minimum wages can be set (otherwise than in the initial making of a modern award) or revoked either under this Part or in annual wage reviews under Part2‑6.

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: all junior employees, or a class of junior employees; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: all employees with a disability, or a class of employees with a disability; or

nodes.label: Subsection 1

nodes.label: Paragraph b

nodes.summary: Amodern enterprise awardis a modern award that is expressed to relate to:

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.summary: one or more enterprises, if the employers all carry on similar business activities under the same franchise and are:

nodes.summary: franchisees of the same franchisor; or

nodes.summary: related bodies corporate of the same franchisor; or

nodes.summary: any combination of the above.

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: a body, association, office or other entity established for a public purpose by or under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; or

nodes.label: Paragraph iii
nodes.summary: any other body in which the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory has a controlling interest.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: For the purposes of subsection(3), if 2 or more employers carry on a business, project or undertaking as a joint venture or common enterprise, the employers are taken to be one employer.

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the bodies corporate are taken to be one employer; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the single enterprises are taken to be one single enterprise.

nodes.label: Subsection 6

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a geographically distinct part of the single enterprise; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: a distinct operational or organisational unit within the single enterprise.

nodes.label: Meanings ofemployeeandemployer
nodes.summary: In this Part,employeemeans a national system employee, andemployermeans a national system employer.

nodes.label: Objects of this Part
nodes.summary:
The objects of this Part are:
(a)to provide a simple, flexible and fair framework that enables collective bargaining in good faith, particularly at the enterprise level, for enterprise agreements that...

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: to provide a simple, flexible and fair framework that enables collective bargaining in good faith, particularly at the enterprise level, for enterprise agreements that deliver productivity benefits; a...

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: to enable the FWC to facilitate good faith bargaining and the making of enterprise agreements, including through:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: makingbargaining orders; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: dealing with disputes where the bargaining representatives request assistance; and

nodes.label: Paragraph iii
nodes.summary: ensuring that applications to the FWC for approval of enterprise agreements are dealt with without delay.

nodes.label: Division 2—Employers and employees may make enterprise agreements
Making an enterprise agreement
nodes.summary:
Enterprise agreements may be made about permitted matters
(1)An agreement (anenterprise agreement) that is about one or more of the following matters (thepermitted matters) may be made in accordance w...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: An agreement (anenterprise agreement) that is about one or more of the following matters (thepermitted matters) may be made in accordance with this Part: Enterprise agreements may be made about permit...

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: matters pertaining to the relationship between an employer that will be covered by the agreement and that employer’s employees who will be covered by the agreement;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: matters pertaining to the relationship between the employer or employers, and the employee organisation or employee organisations, that will be covered by the agreement;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: deductions from wages for any purpose authorised by an employee who will be covered by the agreement;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: how the agreement will operate. Single‑enterprise agreements

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: An employer, or 2 or more employers that are related employers, may make an enterprise agreement (asingle‑enterprise agreement):

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: with the employees who are employed at the time the agreement is made and who will be covered by the agreement; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: with one or more relevant employee organisations if:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: the agreement relates to a genuine new enterprise that the employer or employers are establishing or propose to establish; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the employer or employers have not employed any of the persons who will be necessary for the normal conduct of that enterprise and will be covered by the agreement. Multi‑enterprise agreements

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: Two or more employers that are not all related employers, or that are all related employers mentioned in subsection(3A), may make an enterprise agreement (amulti‑enterprise agreement):

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: with the employees who are employed at the time the agreement is made and who will be covered by the agreement; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: with one or more relevant employee organisations if:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: the agreement relates to a genuine new enterprise that the employers are establishing or propose to establish; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the employers have not employed any of the persons who will be necessary for the normal conduct of that enterprise and will be covered by the agreement. (3A)Two or more employers that are all related...

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: A single‑enterprise agreement made as referred to in paragraph(2)(b), or a multi‑enterprise agreement made as referred to in paragraph(3)(b), is agreenfields agreement. Requirement for employer specif...

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: Despite any other provision of this Part, if an employer is specified in a single interest employer authorisation that is in operation:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the employers are engaged in a joint venture or common enterprise; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employers are related bodies corporate; or

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: the employers carry on similar business activities under the same franchise and are:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: franchisees of the same franchisor; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: related bodies corporate of the same franchisor; or

nodes.label: Paragraph iii
nodes.summary: any combination of the above. Requirement that there be at least 2 employees

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: An enterprise agreement cannot be made with a single employee. Requirement for employer specified in supported bargaining authorisation

nodes.label: Subsection 7
nodes.summary: Despite any other provision of this Part, if an employer is specified in a supported bargaining authorisation that is in operation:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the only kind of enterprise agreement the employer may make with their employees who are specified in the authorisation is a supported bargaining agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the employer must not initiate bargaining, agree to bargain, or be required to bargain with those employees for any other kind of enterprise agreement.

nodes.label: Special measures to achieve equality
nodes.summary: Without limiting subsection172(1), the matters mentioned in paragraph172(1)(a) include special measures to achieve equality.

nodes.summary: If, in proceedings for a pecuniary penalty order against a removed person for a contravention of subsection(3), the person wishes to rely on the exception in subsection(4), the person bears an evident...

nodes.summary: The FWC may, on application in writing by a removed person, grant the person a certificate to be a bargaining representative, if satisfied that the person is a fit and proper person to be a bargaining...

nodes.label: Subsection 8
nodes.summary: In deciding whether the removed person is a fit and proper person to be a bargaining representative, the FWC must have regard to the following matters:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the reasons the person became a removed person, including whether the person engaged or allegedly engaged in a kind of conduct described in subparagraph141(1)(c)(i), (ii) or (iii) of the Registered Or...

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: fraud or dishonesty; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: intentional use of violence against another person; or

nodes.label: Paragraph iii
nodes.summary: intentional damage or destruction of property;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: the general character of the person.

nodes.label: Subsection 9
nodes.summary: The FWC may also have regard to any other matters the FWC considers relevant.

nodes.label: Subsection 10
nodes.summary: The FWC must not grant the certificate:

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Paragraph b

nodes.label: Subsection 11

nodes.label: Subsection 12
nodes.summary: In this section: CFMEUhas the same meaning as in the Registered Organisations Act. Construction and General Divisionhas the same meaning as in the Registered Organisations Act.

nodes.label: Notified negotiation period for a proposed single‑enterprise agreement that is a greenfields agreement

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: If a proposed single‑enterprise agreement is a greenfields agreement, an employer that is a bargaining representative for the agreement may give written notice:

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: stating that the period of 6 months beginning on a specified day is thenotified negotiation periodfor the agreement.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The specified day must be later than:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: if only one employee organisation is a bargaining representative for the agreement—the day on which the employer gave the notice to the organisation; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: if 2 or more employee organisations are bargaining representatives for the agreement—the last day on which the employer gave the notice to any of those organisations. Multiple employers—agreement to g...

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: If 2 or more employers are bargaining representatives for the agreement, the notice has no effect unless the other employer or employers agree to the giving of the notice.

nodes.label: Statement of principles on genuine agreement
nodes.summary:
(1)The FWC must, by legislative instrument, make a statement of principles for employers on ensuring that employees have genuinely agreed to an enterprise agreement.

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: The FWC must, by legislative instrument, make a statement of principles for employers on ensuring that employees have genuinely agreed to an enterprise agreement.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The FWC must publish the statement on the FWC’s website and by any other means that the FWC considers appropriate.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The statement must deal with the following matters:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: informing employees of bargaining for a proposed enterprise agreement;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: informing employees of their right to be represented by a bargaining representative;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: providing employees with a reasonable opportunity to consider a proposed enterprise agreement;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: explaining to employees the terms of a proposed enterprise agreement and their effect;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: providing employees with a reasonable opportunity to vote on a proposed agreement in a free and informed manner, including by informing employees of the time, place and method for the vote;

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: any matter prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this paragraph;

nodes.label: Paragraph g
nodes.summary: any other matters the FWC considers relevant.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: The statement is a legislative instrument, but section42 (disallowance) of theLegislation Act 2003does not apply to the statement.

nodes.label: Paragraph c

nodes.label: Paragraph a

nodes.label: Paragraph b

nodes.label: Subsection 6

nodes.summary: the object of this Act (see section3), and the objects of this Part (see section171);

nodes.label: Paragraph v

nodes.summary: The FWC may approve the variation under section211 if the FWC is satisfied that an undertaking accepted by the FWC under subsection(3) of this section meets the concern. Undertakings

nodes.summary: The FWC may only accept a written undertaking from one or more employers covered by the agreement if the FWC is satisfied that the effect of accepting the undertaking is not likely to:

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: result in substantial changes to the variation. Signature requirements

nodes.label: Division 8—FWC’s general role in facilitating bargaining
Bargaining representatives must meet the good faith bargaining requirements
nodes.summary:
(1)The following are thegood faith bargaining requirementsthat a bargaining representative for a proposed enterprise agreement must meet:
(a)attending, and participating in, meetings at reasonable tim...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: The following are thegood faith bargaining requirementsthat a bargaining representative for a proposed enterprise agreement must meet:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: attending, and participating in, meetings at reasonable times;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: disclosing relevant information (other than confidential or commercially sensitive information) in a timely manner;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: responding to proposals made by other bargaining representatives for the agreement in a timely manner;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: giving genuine consideration to the proposals of other bargaining representatives for the agreement, and giving reasons for the bargaining representative’s responses to those proposals;

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: refraining from capricious or unfair conduct that undermines freedom of association or collective bargaining;

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: recognising and bargaining with the other bargaining representatives for the agreement.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The good faith bargaining requirements do not require:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a bargaining representative to make concessions during bargaining for the agreement; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: a bargaining representative to reach agreement on the terms that are to be included in the agreement.

nodes.label: Applications for bargaining orders
nodes.summary:
Persons who may apply for a bargaining order

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: A bargaining representative for a proposed enterprise agreement may apply to the FWC for an order (abargaining order) under section230 in relation to the agreement. Persons who may apply for a bargain...

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: An application for a bargaining order must not be made in relation to a proposed multi‑enterprise agreement unless a supported bargaining authorisation or single interest employer authorisation is in...

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The application may only be made at whichever of the following times applies:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: if one or more enterprise agreements apply to an employee, or employees, who will be covered by the proposed enterprise agreement:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: not more than 90 days before the nominal expiry date of the enterprise agreement, or the latest nominal expiry date of those enterprise agreements (as the case may be); or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: after an employer that will be covered by the proposed enterprise agreement has requested under subsection181(1) that employees approve the agreement, but before the agreement is so approved;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: otherwise—at any time. Prerequisites for making an application

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: The bargaining representative may only apply for the bargaining order if the bargaining representative:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: has concerns that:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: one or more of the bargaining representatives for the agreement have not met, or are not meeting, the good faith bargaining requirements; or

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the bargaining process is not proceeding efficiently or fairly because there are multiple bargaining representatives for the agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: has given a written notice setting out those concerns to the relevant bargaining representatives; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: has given the relevant bargaining representatives a reasonable time within which to respond to those concerns; and

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: considers that the relevant bargaining representatives have not responded appropriately to those concerns. Non‑compliance with notice requirements may be permitted

nodes.label: Subsection 5
nodes.summary: The FWC may consider the application even if it does not comply with paragraph(4)(b) or (c) if the FWC is satisfied that it is appropriate in all the circumstances to do so.

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: the bargaining process is not proceeding efficiently or fairly because there are multiple bargaining representatives for the agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: that the applicant has complied with the requirements of subsection229(4) (which deals with notifying relevant bargaining representatives of concerns), unless subsection229(5) permitted the applicant...

nodes.summary: any other matter prescribed by the procedural rules. Operation of declaration

nodes.summary: ceases to be in operation when each employer specified in the declaration is covered by an enterprise agreement or a workplace determination. End of the minimum bargaining period

nodes.summary: the day that is 9 months after the day bargaining starts, as worked out under subsection(6); or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the day that is 9 months after the day bargaining starts, as worked out under subsection(6).

nodes.label: Subsection 6
nodes.summary: For the purposes of subparagraph(5)(a)(ii) and paragraph(5)(b), the day bargaining starts for a proposed agreement is:

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: otherwise—the notification time for the proposed agreement.

nodes.label: Paragraph c

nodes.label: Entitlement for volunteer bodies to make submissions
nodes.summary:
(1)A body covered by subsection(2) is entitled to make a submission for consideration in relation to a matter before the FWC if:
(a)the matter arises under this Part; and
(b)the matter affects, or cou...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: A body covered by subsection(2) is entitled to make a submission for consideration in relation to a matter before the FWC if:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: the matter arises under this Part; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: the matter affects, or could affect, the volunteers of a designated emergency management body.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The bodies are as follows:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a body corporate that:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: has a history of representing the interests of the designated emergency management body’s volunteers; and

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: is not prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this subparagraph;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: any other body that is prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this paragraph.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: Subsection(1) applies whether or not the FWC holds a hearing in relation to the matter.

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: This Part does not empower the FWC to make an order that requires, or has the effect of requiring:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: particular content to be included or not included in a proposed enterprise agreement; or

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: an employer to request under subsection181(1) that employees approve a proposed enterprise agreement; or

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: an employee to approve, or not approve, a proposed enterprise agreement; or

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: an employer to give a notice under section178B; or

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: an employer to specify a particular day in a notice under section178B; or

nodes.label: Paragraph f
nodes.summary: an employer to agree to the giving of a notice under section178B.

nodes.label: Limitations relating to greenfields agreements
nodes.summary:
(1)If:
(a)a proposed single‑enterprise agreement is a greenfields agreement; and
(b)there has been a notified negotiation period for the agreement; and
(c)the notified negotiation period has ended;
(d...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: If:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a proposed single‑enterprise agreement is a greenfields agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: there has been a notified negotiation period for the agreement; and

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: the notified negotiation period has ended;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: the following provisions do not apply in relation to the agreement at any time after the end of the notified negotiation period:

nodes.label: Paragraph i
nodes.summary: section228 (which deals with good faith bargaining requirements);

nodes.label: Paragraph ii
nodes.summary: sections229 and 230 (which deal with bargaining orders);

nodes.label: Paragraph iii
nodes.summary: sections234 and 235 (which deal with serious breach declarations);

nodes.label: Paragraph iv
nodes.summary: section240 (which deals with bargaining disputes); and

nodes.label: Paragraph e
nodes.summary: a bargaining order that relates to the agreement ceases to have effect at the end of the notified negotiation period.

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: Paragraph(1)(e) has effect despite anything in section232 (which deals with the operation of bargaining orders).

nodes.label: Prospective employers and employees
nodes.summary: A reference to an employer, or an employee, in relation to a greenfields agreement, includes a reference to a person who may become an employer or employee.

nodes.label: How employees, employers and employee organisations are to be described
nodes.summary: (1)This section applies if a provision of this Part requires or permits an instrument of any kind to specify the employers, employees or employee organisations covered, or who will be covered, by an e...

nodes.label: Subsection 1
nodes.summary: This section applies if a provision of this Part requires or permits an instrument of any kind to specify the employers, employees or employee organisations covered, or who will be covered, by an ente...

nodes.label: Subsection 2
nodes.summary: The employees may be specified by class or by name.

nodes.label: Subsection 3
nodes.summary: The employers and employee organisations must be specified by name.

nodes.label: Subsection 4
nodes.summary: Without limiting the way in which a class may be described for the purposes of subsection(2), the class may be described by reference to one or more of the following:

nodes.label: Paragraph a
nodes.summary: a particular industry or part of an industry;

nodes.label: Paragraph b
nodes.summary: a particular kind of work;

nodes.label: Paragraph c
nodes.summary: a particular type of employment;

nodes.label: Paragraph d
nodes.summary: a particular classification, job level or grade.
